Bacterial blight

 

DESCRIPTION

Older lower leaves become yellow.  The leaves gradually turn brown from the leaf edge showing a blighted appearance and the crop has shorter life span if not managed immediately and properly.  In resistant varieties, the leaves have slight yellow color and form in angular leaf spots.

 

CONTROL MEASURE

  • Remove yellowing leaves and burn or bury deep in the soil outside the production area.

  • Plant a resistant variety.

  • Do not use infected plant as planting material.

Gummy stem blight

Fungi (Phoma cucurbitacearum; Didymella bryoniae)

 

DESCRIPTION

Lesion is usually V -or U-shape with light brown on leaf edges and expand to the center. Stem lesion is light brown and often elongated. Older leaves become yellowish and die. Fruit infection usually starts from blossom end.

 

CONTROL MEASURE

  • Use resistant varieties.

  • Do not use infected seeds.

  • Avoid prolonged moisture.

  • Practice crop rotation.

  • Spray fungicides if necessary.

Barako

 

DESCRIPTION

It is caused by a mycoplasma-like pathogen.  Infected plants have shortened vines, small leaves and malformed (wrinkled) leaves near the shoot that is visible when the plant has one-meter-long vine.  The quality of leaves and fruits is inferior.

 

CONTROL MEASURE

  • Uproot the whole plant and burn.

  • Do not use infected seeds.

Downy mildew

Causal Organism: Peronospora sparsa

 

DESCRIPTION

Pathogen is an obligate parasite and infects cucurbit crops. It occurs in temperate and tropical areas (high or low rainfall as long as the leaf is wet or dew). High humidity (100% for 6 hours) with moderate temperatures (15-30 °C). Sporangia are spread by wind, rain splashes, contact with workers and tools.

 

CONTROL MEASURE

  • Use resistant varieties.

  • Remove infected leaves.

  • Spray with protectant and systemic fungicides.

  • Avoid prolonged leaf wetness by providing good air circulation. 

  • Sterilize agricultural tools.

Namamarako or NMK caused by Polerovirus (Cucurbit aphid borne yellow virus, CABV)

 

DESCRIPTION

Namamarako or maleness in which the leaves are wrinkled followed by thickening of the older leaves which appears shiny or plastic appearance; older leaves have yellow patches and the number of female flowers is reduced; and stunted and male flowers are hardly produced (severe infection).

 

CONTROL MEASURE

  • Regular monitoring.

  • Use resistant/tolerant varieties.

  • Remove infected plants. 

  • Remove weeds.

  • Manage aphid population using plastic mulch, yellow sticky traps and/or insecticides
